heading: revamped 'spambone' launched
subheading: once planning to become the "all-spam network," the isp co-founded by retired spam-king sanford wallace launches a more controlled plan for distributing advertiser email.
author: wired news report
text: the network once global technology marketing internationalnow, gtmi is billing itself as an isp for advertisers -- or, in the company's words, a direct commercial email advertising network. rather than hiding out on other isps, advertisers are free to use gtmi to distribute their bulk email. but instead of blasting messages to every internet address it can find, gtmi will pay isps for each piece of advertising that is accepted."each isp is free to set its own price for access by advertisers," the company's announcement says, "and choose which of its subscribers are part of the system."last month, gtmi co-founder sanford wallace -- formerly the hated "king of spam" -- the company, too, is contrite. its announcement shows an eagerness to reposition itself in the eyes of spam-haters everywhere: "initially touted as the 'all-spam' network, the gtmi system is now a 'closed' 100 percent isp-level, opt-in system," the statement promises. in other words, email access is controlled and restricted to the network itself rather than spilling out onto the entire internet.
